introductionMessages.single: You play against bots; bots have limited coins, sometimes you’ll have to sell kittens one by one not all at once. Your task is to earn more coins than bots. Be attentive; each season kitten prices update. {{seasonsMessage}}.
introductionMessages.team: Now you play in a team of 5; depending on your role you have certain functions.  {{seasonsMessage}}. Team goal is to have the most money by the end of the last season. Good luck!

corp.ceo: Now you have the chance to manage not just one team but {{teamsCount}} teams at once. Set delegation to match your strategy, define spending limits, and allocate budget per city. {{seasonsMessage}}. Remember you own the corporation and your goal is to have the most money by the end of the last season. Good luck!
corp.default: You play in a team of 5 but now there’s a CEO who sets strategy for the whole corporation. Depending on your role you have specific functions. {{seasonsMessage}}. Team goal is to have the most money by the end of the last season across the corporation. Good luck!

introductionMessages.realtime: In this mode you play without exact seasons and need to monitor all actions in real time. Good luck!

content.main: Business Cats is a multiplayer online economic strategy (business simulation) game. The goal of the game is to obtain the maximum possible profit.
content.seasons: The game is divided into seasons. A season ends with the game turn.

balance.title: Balance
balance.description: Detailed data about the organization’s assets, income, and expenses.

utilities.title: Utilities
utilities.description: Delivering water, heat, gas, and other services necessary for comfortable living.

nursery.title: Cattery
nursery.description: A place or establishment for growing and breeding plants or animals.

margin.title: Margin
margin.description: The difference between selling price and purchase cost per cat on average.

profit.title: Profit
profit.description: The amount by which income exceeds expenses.

deal.title: Deal
deal.description: Agreement between two parties to fulfill certain obligations.

segmentation.title: Market segmentation
segmentation.description: Dividing the market into clear buyer groups so each group can be offered a suitable product.

season.title: Game season
season.description: Game turn. One season equals three months.

demand.title: Demand
demand.description: It’s the consumer’s desire to buy a specific product or service at a specific price over a certain period.

costs.title: Operating expenses
costs.description: The upkeep costs the owner has to bear.

crossbreeding.title: Breeding
crossbreeding.description: One method of breeding plants and animals.

scale.title: Scale effect
scale.description: Reducing production costs through increased production volume.

pricing.title: Pricing
pricing.description: The process of forming the product price.

SINGLE.title: blue row with maroon horizontal lines or “revolving loan” - short-term bank loan to cover operating expenses like utilities, feed, insurance.

content.seasonsNote: The number of seasons for each game type is specified in the session starting parameters

single.description1: Single mode is a solo game with bots (
single.description2: emoji, because the biggest discount you asked for was
single.description3: ). At this stage the participant must complete the tutorial and single games as a cattery and a pet shop. As both cattery and pet shop you need to win. After that the participant moves to the “Solo” mode.

solo.description: Solo mode is a multiplayer game where players compete. In this mode there is only one bot—a pet shop.

team.description: Team game is a multiplayer team business simulation. Players unite into teams playing one of the roles. Gameplay is similar to Solo but split by team roles.

corporate.description: Unlike Team mode, the team captain loses autonomy and reports to the CEO (director). The CEO manages five captains in different cities. Each city has its own demand.

realtime.description: Realtime mode is a new simulation type based on Business Cats Solo. The main difference is fully removing season timers, so all actions happen in real minutes.

content.main: Pet shops and catteries play in the simulation.
content.playersCount: Maximum players in the game: 20 catteries and 5 pet shops, one of which is a bot.
content.roles: If your role is a pet shop, catteries are your business partners (counterparties) and other pet shops are competitors. If you play as a cattery it’s the opposite.

TIMERS.title: since we now build the business plan around the long-term deal, we need to change the Revenue fields. We must calculate long-term deal stage percentages for “Advance,” “Before shipment,” and “After shipment”

content.main: Business Cats Realtime is a new Business Cats simulation mode. Its main mechanic differing from other versions is completely removing season timers, so all actions happen in real minutes. This version is based on Business Cats Solo and repeats most Solo mechanics.

timers.title: Timers
timers.description: In Realtime, “Season” from the Solo version is replaced by the concept of a “quarter” split into three in-game months. The game counts forward from 00:00, unlike other versions with a countdown.
timers.additional: Besides the month timer the simulation has timers for the following mechanics; each timer is set for one in-game month and configured before session start in the admin panel.

growingUp.title: Cats growing up
growingUp.description: A kitten becomes adult after 9 in-game months. The timer starts from the kitten’s birth or from purchase from the city / pet shop bot; i.e., when the pet shop buys the cat from the city, the growth timer starts. One month of growth equals 1 in-game month.

mating.title: Breeding cats
mating.description: Breeding cats lasts 3 in-game months. The timer starts when the user clicks “Breed.” You can’t breed cats younger than 9 months.
mating.additional: If during breeding the father runs away from hunger but the mother remains in the house, breeding won’t stop and kittens will still be born.
mating.rest: Cat rest lasts 3 in-game months. The timer starts from when the pair’s kittens are just born.

insurance.title: Insurance
insurance.description: House insurance lasts 3 in-game months. Timer starts when buying insurance. Clicking the house insurance button again extends it and starts another 3-month timer. When time expires the house is uninsured. Kittens born while insurance is active are treated for free; if the player buys insurance after breeding, treatment is paid because insurance expires in time.

runaway.title: Conditions under which a cat runs away
runaway.description: Cats running away is divided into two types:
types: Without a house—in this case cats will run away after 3 in-game months. The countdown starts when the pet shop buys from the city; when the pet shop sells the cat to the cattery this counter resets and counts until the cat is in a house. The counter also starts when a cat is moved from a house to the buffer (behind the fence) for a cat.
From illness/hunger – in this case cats run away after 1 in-game month. The countdown starts when the cat gets at least one status (hunger/illness).

hungry.title: Conditions under which a cat becomes hungry
hungry.description: A cat will become hungry after 3 in-game months. The timer starts from birth or purchase from the city, or from the previous feeding. The deal window will also show the hungry cat status without and with the magnifier.

utilities.title: Utilities
utilities.description: Utilities will be charged every 3 in-game months. The timer starts when the simulation launches and after paying utilities.

cityDemand.title: City demand
cityDemand.description: City demand recovers quarterly, considering months and minutes when kittens were sold. Demand recovers for a set number of minutes.
cityDemand.formula: Cat recovery = the initially set time per month * 3, where 3 is a constant for 3 in-game months.
cityDemand.explanation: This implementation also changes price return logic: now kitten prices return to start via “steps.” A step means the price drops to the next cheaper cat once demand is satisfied. Prices rise in reverse as demand recovers step by step. Below is an example of price returning for LDS and LMS.
cityDemand.example: In this example the price for LDS fell in minute 2 of month X and recovered only by minute 3 of month X + 3. In other words, this mechanic is closely tied to the time it takes to restore demand for cats.

credits.title: Loans
credits.description: Loans will be charged automatically every 3 in-game months. The timer starts when the loan is taken; if the loan spans several quarters, the timer resets after paying a part. If the person has no money at payment time, they are immediately declared bankrupt. The taken loans window shows all active loans and their payment deadlines; at the top the nearest payment among all loans is shown; if multiple loans share a due time, the combined payment amount is shown.

balanceDetail.title: Balance breakdown
balanceDetail.description: Reports are generated every 3 in-game months. The timer starts when the game launches and runs until session end. Upon receiving a report, the next report timer starts. Quarterly reports include the same data as seasons in Solo.

seasonChange.title: Season change
seasonChange.description: The changing background will switch every 3 in-game months. Timer starts when the session starts. Initial background is summer, then autumn, winter, and spring.

mainSection.title: Main screen
mainSection.description1: All players’ houses are in the center of the screen. Your house is additionally highlighted.
mainSection.description2: The game is time-limited. The current season and timer are shown at the top of the screen.
mainSection.description3: If desired, the player can end the season early by clicking “End season” in the top right. Then they can cancel if they change their mind.
mainSection.description4: Next to the end season button are the settings, voice chat, and session participants buttons.
mainSection.description5: The settings button lets you manage modal messages, sounds, music, and return to the HR platform.
mainSection.description6: Voice chat lets players talk to each other if their role allows it.
mainSection.description7: The list of all session participants and their competencies is available by clicking the button with the corresponding icon.
mainSection.description8: The main screen also shows the player icon and the number of coins on their account.

balance.title: Detailed balance
balance.description1: Clicking the coin next to your icon opens the detailed balance.
balance.description2: The balance shows the starting number of coins at the start of the season, the player’s expenses and income, and information on whom deals were made with in the current season. Next are receiving and repaying the loan principal. At the bottom of the balance card the profit and number of coins at the moment are shown.
balance.description3: In the business simulation each role has its own expenses.
balance.expensesPetshop: Pet shop expenses = utilities + buying cats + interest payments.
balance.expensesNursery: Cattery expenses = buying cats + utilities + feeding cats + buying a house + insuring the house + treating cats + interest payments.
balance.income: Pet shops and catteries earn income from selling kittens. Pet shops trade with the city and with catteries. A cattery can trade only with pet shops.

sessionPlayers.title: Session players
sessionPlayers.description: During the game you can click the player list button in the top right. A window will open with session participants and their competence levels.

voiceChat.title: Voice chat
voiceChat.description: The game has voice and text chat. Voice chat is available in all modes except Single and Training.

personalArea.title: Personal cabinet
personalArea.description1: In their personal cabinet the cattery player sees all cats they have on the area by the fence and in the pet houses.
personalArea.description2: The cattery shows the request feed on the right (see
personalArea.description5: On the left is a panel with 4 buttons

houses.title: Houses for kittens
houses.description1: The cattery buys a pet house for 3 coins.
houses.description2: The house has 4 windows for raising and breeding adult pairs and 12 small windows for newborn kittens. Under the parents’ windows are buttons with the “Breed” function.
houses.description3: Newborn kitten slots cannot be occupied by purchased cats.
houses.description4: Without houses cats do not breed and run away at the end of the season.
houses.description5: Hungry and sick kittens also run away whether in a house or on the yard.

cats.title: Cats
cats.description1: In the game you can sell and buy male and female kittens of four different colors. Each season kittens in the cattery grow up. Kitten age counts from 0. Kittens are considered small up to age 3 seasons.
cats.description4: Be attentive: sick and hungry cats will run away at the end of the turn! Kittens left without a house will also leave the cattery.

feeding.title: Feeding
feeding.description1: When cats are hungry, they meow and an empty bowl appears next to them.
feeding.description2: The cattery can feed cats in two ways:
feeding.method2: double-click the feed icon to feed kittens one by one left to right
feeding.description3: When feeding a cat, the player sees a modal to confirm their actions.
feeding.description4: You can’t feed one cat twice in a season.

crossbreeding.title: Breeding
crossbreeding.description1: The pet house windows let you breed and produce offspring. The “Breed” button is active when male and female kittens live together in one half of the house, are grown up, and are fed.
crossbreeding.description2: During breeding cats cannot be moved.
crossbreeding.description3: Offspring appears in the next season after breeding. One pair gives birth to 6 kittens (2 males and 1 female of the mother’s color, 2 males and 1 female of the father’s color).
crossbreeding.description4: Kittens are placed next to the mother in the newborn kitten slots.
crossbreeding.description5: No need to feed kittens while they’re with their mom. But if you separate them from the mother cat, you must feed them every turn.
crossbreeding.description6: Cats don’t breed if kittens sit with them or if 1 season hasn’t passed since the last breeding.
crossbreeding.description7: When the newborn kittens grow up, they move from the house to the yard.

diseases.title: Diseases and their treatment
diseases.description1: If you hover the magnifier over a kitten, you can find the sick pet.
diseases.description2: Treatments (bandage, ointment, shampoo, pills) are available during cat inspection. If the house wasn’t insured at kitten birth, treatment costs 2 coins (see
diseases.description5: If you don’t treat a cat, it will run away at the start of the next season.
diseases.description6: A cat can be sick with the following diseases:

insurance.title: Insurance
insurance.description1: Each cattery house can be insured for one season. Click the insurance button.
insurance.description2: Insurance covers treatment costs for kittens in the insured house in the next season.
insurance.description3: After insuring, an insurance icon appears above the house.

utilities.title: Utilities
utilities.description1: Each season the player pays for utilities.
utilities.description2: Utilities for the cattery cost 3 coins. Money is deducted at season end. This expense is shown in the detailed balance at season start.

personalArea.title: Personal cabinet
personalArea.description1: The pet shop house shows all cats that exist in the simulator (see
personalArea.description3: ), indicating how many kittens that player has. The pet shop player's house has a magnifier to inspect kittens.

demand.title: Demand
demand.description: There is demand in the city for each type of cat. Only pet shops can see city demand because prices at which shops sell kittens to the city depend on it.
demand.dynamics: During the season city dwellers’ demand for cats changes. For example, once wealthy citizens buy up expensive kittens, the city starts buying such kittens at a lower price (at the price of the next cheaper type)—bought by middle-income residents. When demand among the middle class is satisfied, the price drops again and the originally “elite” kittens become available to low-income residents.
demand.priceNote: At the same time the city’s price for selling cats to the pet shop doesn’t change.

utilities.title: Utilities
utilities.description: Each season the player pays for utilities.
utilities.cost: Utilities for the pet shop cost 1 coin. Money is deducted from the player’s account at season end. This expense is shown in the detailed balance at season start.

content.main1: Trading is only with opponents. Trading with competitors is impossible. To propose a deal to a cattery/pet shop, enter that player’s house. Only kittens are sold. (see
content.shopTrade: If you play as a pet shop, the trade window lets you trade with the city and with the cattery.
content.shopDescription: Trade window for the pet shop player.
content.applicationsNote1: Requests appear on the right in the feed (see
content.cityTrade: The top row shows the cats available for deals with the city. It also shows the prices to sell kittens to the city and to buy kittens from the city. To sell a kitten to the city, drag a kitten from your showcase to the city showcase.
content.cityPurchase: To buy a kitten from the city, drag a kitten from the city showcase into your area.
content.playerCats: Under the city cats are the player’s cats showing quantities and prices. Clicking your cat lets you change the kitten’s buy and sell prices.
content.dealZone: Under the pet shop player’s showcase is the deal area. Pet shop requests to trade with catteries are formed here. Incoming deals and counter offers are shown when clicking the corresponding envelope in the request feed.
content.nurseryTrade: Trade window for the cattery player.
content.nurseryDescription: Playing as a cattery, the trade window only allows trading with the pet shop; catteries do not trade with the city.

presets.title: Preset prices
presets.description: Preset prices are the initial prices for each type of cat for all players.
presets.change: Preset prices can be changed by players at any time during the game. To do so go into the opponent’s or competitor’s house and click your cat in your showcase whose price you want to change. Change sale or purchase price and save.

applications.title: Requests
applications.description: All requests are displayed on every screen on the right in the highlighted request block.
applications.icons: Requests are marked with sender icons and a request-type symbol.

type1.name: outgoing request
type1.description: All purchase or sale requests you sent.

type2.name: incoming request
type2.description: All incoming requests from other players.

type3.name: request rejected (by another player)
type3.description: If the opponent rejects your request, it will be marked with this envelope.

type4.name: accepted request (by another player)
type4.description: If the opponent accepts your incoming or counter request, the request will be marked with this envelope.

type5.name: counter request
type5.description: If the opponent changes prices, quantities, or types of kittens in your deal and returns it with new data, the request is marked as counter. You must review it and then reject or approve.

type6.name: request requiring clarification
type6.description: This request type needs attention. Requests with kittens sold to someone else are marked this way. Such requests must be reviewed: cancel or change.

type7.name: request pending clarification (with another player)
type7.description: If the seller’s situation with kittens changes and they revise the request, the buyer is in waiting state.

applications.details: All request data is shown in the deal area when you click the corresponding requests

corporation.title: Corporation
corporation.description: In the corporate simulation version a CEO (director) appeared who manages five captains in different cities. If in Single, Solo, and Team modes the game took place in one city, the corporate version has 5 independent cities each with its own demand and prices for cats.
corporation.structure: There are 24 CEOs in the game, each with 5 teams, one in each city. All five teams share one role—either pet shop or cattery.

ceo.title: CEO
ceo.description: The CEO (director) sets the company strategy. The corporate simulation version added many new tools to help achieve maximum profit.

ceoPowers.title: CEO powers
ceoPowers.description: The CEO’s authority includes delegating actions, approving and setting limits for actions they don’t approve personally, allocating budget between the CEO account and cities, transporting cats between cities, making long-term deals, taking loans, selling cats on the export market, buying cats on the import market, and ending the turn early.

ceoMainScreen.title: CEO main screen
ceoMainScreen.description: Let’s review all game elements on the CEO main screen
ceoMainScreen.profile: In the top left we see the player icon, corporation name, and CEO account balance; clicking it shows reports of all corporate financial transactions.
ceoMainScreen.delegation: The button for configuring delegation and setting limits.
ceoMainScreen.cities: 5 cities we can switch to in order to visit one of our teams, competitors, or counterparties.
ceoMainScreen.airport: The airport, where we can make import/export deals and track already formed deals.
ceoMainScreen.office: The “Your office” building, where we can make long-term deals, allocate budget between cities, and move cats between cities within our corporation.

agreement.title: Coordination of corporation actions
agreement.description: Directly the CEO doesn’t delegate duties but can control all operations happening in the cities.
agreement.modes: For control he can switch the toggle in three modes:
modesList: CEO - in this mode the CEO personally approves all operations in the selected items.
Captain - the CEO doesn’t approve requests himself but requires the captain to check all operations.
Team - everything works like Team mode: the captain chooses what to approve and what to delegate to the team.
agreement.checkbox: The checkbox before the toggle lets you give the team new permissions. For example, allowing the team to take a loan opens bank access to the marketer.
agreement.settings: Delegation and limits can be configured for all cities at once or per city separately.
agreement.notification: When approval status changes, the captain receives a modal notification.

limits.title: Operation limits
limits.description: If the CEO doesn’t personally approve expense items, they can limit them each season. If they check the box at the end of the approval window, they can set limits for the current season. If the team needs to exceed the limit, the CEO will receive an approval request. Besides expense limits, the CEO can set a deviation from showcase prices.

office.title: CEO Office
office.description: Clicking “Your office” opens a window with three tabs: “Budget,” “Deals,” “Transportation”
office.utilities: Utilities to maintain the CEO office for the cattery are 3 coins, and for the pet shop CEO 1 coin.

budget.title: Budget
budget.purpose: Available budget is the CEO budget. It is needed to pay for imports, CEO office utilities, loan payments if the CEO took a corporate loan, buying vehicles, and paying for long-term deals.
budget.allocation: To allocate money from the CEO budget, enter an amount in the desired city window and click the green “Allocate” button. Allocation requires approval. Until approval the amount isn’t allocated and can be changed.
budget.withdrawal: To take money from one of the cities, do the same steps but click the red “Withdraw” button instead of the green one.

longTermDeals.title: Long-term deals
longTermDeals.description: Long-term deals are concluded at the CEO-to-CEO level.
longTermDeals.creation: To proceed to the deal choose a counterparty, city to receive cats or ship from, specify deal type (purchase, sale, or both) and click create.

transportation.title: Transporting cats between cities
transportation.description: In the Single, Solo, and Team versions the simulation took place within one city. Now each corporation has one branch in each of the 5 cities.
transportation.role: In the corporate simulation version you can transport cats between your corporation’s cities. The CEO handles transporting cats between cities for both cattery and pet shop.
transportation.vehicles: Transporting cats requires cars. There are two types: for 6 cats and for 12 cats. A vehicle can be bought for the whole game or rented for 1 season.
transportation.rules: In one season each car can transport only one batch of cats, and the cats arrive at the destination only the next season after sending. The cats must be fed and healthy or they will run away during transport.

exportImport.title: Export/import
exportImport.description: In the Single, Solo, and Team versions you could trade the cheapest cats with the pet shop bot; in the Corp version import and export markets appeared. Only the CEO can trade cats with the external world.
exportImport.features: Export and import prices are set at session start and don’t change. Key factors are delivery time and deferred payment.

import.title: Import
import.description: Buying via import has a 2-season delay. Cats arrive in the specified city at age 1 season. 30% of the deal amount must be paid when making the deal; the remaining 70% is paid in the delivery season.
import.example: Example: we buy two cats in season 1 for 40 coins total. Choose the delivery city and pay 12 coins when making the deal. Cats arrive in season 3, then we pay the remaining 28 coins. In season 3 we have a pair of 1-season-old kittens that will give offspring in season 6

export.title: Export
export.description: Selling via export has a 3-season delay. 30% of the deal amount is received when making the deal; the remaining 70% arrives in 3 seasons.
export.conditions: To sell via the export market the cats must be fed and healthy; otherwise the deal can’t be made.
export.example: Example: we sell four cats in season 6 for 90 coins. First choose the shipping city, move cats to the deal area, and send the deal. We get 27 coins immediately; the remaining 63 arrive at the start of season 9. Remember that because of payment delay, selling via export is possible up to 3 seasons before game end. In a 14-season session, the last export season is season 11.

market.title: Market
market.description: The game has 5 independent cities, each with its own demand and prices for cats. Cats across the 5 cities stay in the same price category: if the ginger cat is most expensive in city 1, it is also most expensive in all other cities.
market.dynamics: Cat prices and demand change along the demand pyramid. If we buy a lot from the city, price rises and demand falls; if we sell a lot to the city, price falls and demand rises.

balance.title: My Balance
balance.description: In the “My balance” window you can see all corporate financial transactions. The window is tabbed by seasons and by cities.
balance.corporationTab: The “Corporation” tab provides reporting for the whole corporation. It collects info on all CEO expenses and income, as well as sums of expenses and income from all 5 cities. Money at start and end of season are calculated as the sum of the CEO account and team accounts across all 5 cities.
balance.citiesTab: The city tabs collect detailed info on a city’s expenses and income, excluding common expense/income items and CEO operations.

content.main: In any game mode there is one pet shop bot controlled by AI, not a human.
content.singleMode: In single mode all catteries and pet shops except the player are bots.

relations.title: Relations
relations.description: If the player is a cattery, all pet shop bots are marked with emojis—relationship indicators between the player and the pet shop.
relations.shopPerspective1: If the player is a pet shop, all cattery bots are marked with emojis (depends on game mode, see
relations.initial: Emojis show the bot’s attitude to the player. Initially each bot likes the player at +5—a green happy emoji.
relations.location: The relationship emoji is shown on the main screen next to the bot’s house and in the deal window with the bot.
relations.typesTitle: Types of relationships to the player:
relations.type1: Red – the bot is dissatisfied with your business policy. The emoji turns red when relations drop to 0; then the bot stops contacting and trading with the player.
relations.type2: Light red – the bot dislikes your business policy; it will be quite hard to agree.
relations.type3: Ginger – the bot is puzzled by your business policy but you can still negotiate.
relations.type4: Yellow – the bot is neutral to your negotiation policy; it will be a bit harder to agree.
relations.type5: Light green – the bot likes your business policy; it’s easier to agree.
relations.type6: Green – relations with the bot are good, it’s easier to reach agreement. Set initially.

content.main: Each player can take a loan from the bot. There are 3 loans in the game. They differ by repayment methods and fixed rate. Players aren’t limited by loan count if total borrowing doesn’t exceed the limit. Payment happens automatically at season end, but the player can repay early to reduce interest overpayment.

consumer.name: Consumer loan
consumer.description: loan with minimal bank risk; principal and interest are paid together at term end. Highest interest rate.

special.name: Loan with special terms
special.description: the riskiest loan for the bank; principal and interest paid together at loan end. Highest loan rate.

calculate.title: calculation
calculate.description: When entering coins and seasons you will see overpayment for a specific loan, and by clicking “Calculate” you can compute each loan and see per-season payments.

getCredit.title: receiving
getCredit.description: Clicking “Receive” sends a request to the bank; the decision will determine whether you get the loan. You can see the bank’s decision in the corresponding notification.

active.title: taken loans
active.description: In the “Taken loans data” tab you can see all active loans and information on them: principal, interest, per-season payments.

creditRepayment.title: early repayment
creditRepayment.description: The game allows early repayment, which you can perform by clicking the blue early repayment button. In this case you will pay only half of the unaccrued interest on the remaining principal. The loan cannot be repaid early in the last turn of the loan.

CREATING_CLOSURE.title: creating a purchase and sale deal

content.main: Long-term deals can span several seasons. The ability to set fines for poor performance makes the deal safe, and a bank guarantee helps recover investments in critical situations.

creatingClosure.title: Creating a deal
creatingClosure.description: In the game you can make a long-term deal by visiting a cattery/pet shop and clicking the long-term deal button.
creatingClosure.types: A long-term deal is concluded for purchase or sale separately, or purchase and sale in one deal.
creatingClosure.structure: A long-term deal consists of 6 blocks: subject, delivery order, payment order, security, liability, termination.
creatingClosure.fields: Fields marked green/brown are required. Fields marked purple are optional.
creatingClosure.process: Delivering cats and paying follow the standard flow: advance payment, delivery to warehouse, payment before shipment, shipment from warehouse, payment after shipment. These steps secure the deal and let each side plan when it gets cats or money. Advance and post-shipment payments may not coincide with the delivery season.
creatingClosure.selection: Choose the needed kittens, set the quantity and price for each.
creatingClosure.delivery: After choosing the cats set the delivery season when we want to receive or send cats. When we select the needed delivery season, all timers fill automatically but we can edit them if needed.
creatingClosure.timing: In the delivery/payment order items there are required season values for operations and time frames. Time there is counted from the end of the season (10 minutes before season end). Time limits are important for timely fulfillment of obligations. They determine whether claims and fines can be issued. If one stage is late, the rest shift by the delay time.
creatingClosure.warehouse: There is a warehouse in the game. The seller temporarily places cats there and informs the buyer they can inspect them. Until the buyer inspects the cats, the seller cannot manage them. After the buyer makes the “before shipment” payment, they can pick up the cats with the seller’s approval.
creatingClosure.paymentStructure: Payment is split into 3 parts: advance, before shipment, after shipment. By default money is allocated: advance 30%, before shipment 60%, after shipment 10%, but these can be changed as long as the payments total the deal amount. Any field can be set to zero.
creatingClosure.paymentTerms: "Advance" must be paid before the kittens are shipped to the warehouse. The "before shipment" payment must be paid in the delivery season before confirming the kittens in the warehouse. The "after shipment" payment is paid after the kittens are shipped.

responsibility.title: Liability
responsibility.description: If the other side breaks agreements, the player can send a claim and wait for fix, or issue a fine after which the deal is automatically terminated. You can issue a fine without a claim if you can’t negotiate a resolution.
responsibility.reasons: Grounds for claims and fines include late payment, late delivery and underdelivery, and sick cats in the deal. The fine amount and form are set when forming the long-term deal.
responsibility.latePayment: The late payment penalty can be a fixed coin amount, a percentage of the total deal, or a percentage of the delayed operation. Max penalty is {max_fine}% of the deal amount.
responsibility.lateDelivery: The penalty for late delivery/underdelivery is paid in two cases: the supplier didn’t send to warehouse or ship on time, or not all cats arrived at the warehouse.
responsibility.lateDeliveryTypes: The penalty for late delivery/underdelivery can be a fixed coin amount, a percentage of the total deal, or a percentage of the undelivered cats.
responsibility.quality: Quality penalty is applied if sick cats are in the deal. It can be a fixed amount in coins, a percentage of the total deal amount, or a percentage of all sick cats.
responsibility.replacement: Cats can be replaced with healthy ones if the receiving side sends a claim instead of a fine.

bankGuarantee.title: Bank guarantee
bankGuarantee.description: You can use a bank guarantee so the counterparty is sure it will cover your obligations if you go bankrupt. You can also specify its amount to the counterparty for assurance.
bankGuarantee.payment: A bank guarantee is taken for the duration of the whole deal, and you can pay for it in the deal conclusion season (5% of the amount) or spread it over several seasons; then the payment is calculated as: BG amount * (0.05 + ((number of seasons - 1) / 100)) / number of seasons), i.e., 1% is added for each season of payments.

termination.title: Termination
termination.description: Terminating a long-term deal is possible in four cases: unilateral termination with the fixed payment, termination by mutual agreement, termination due to a fine, or auto-termination at season end.
termination.conditions: If in the termination terms you set “no termination conditions,” there will be no unilateral termination. You can also choose a fixed payment or a percentage of the total deal amount.
termination.automatic: If liability is provided and a fine is imposed for nonperformance, the deal is automatically terminated as soon as someone issues the fine. Similarly, the deal is terminated if by season end there is an unfinished action. Whoever stalled the deal must pay the fine.
termination.guarantee: If liability is not specified but there is a bank guarantee, the fine must be paid by general law depending on the violation: late payment - 50% of the unpaid amount; late delivery to warehouse - 50% of the price of undelivered cats; late shipment from warehouse - 50% of the price of cats at the warehouse. For sick cats there is no bank guarantee payment.

executionOfObligations.title: Obligation fulfillment
executionOfObligations.signing: Once the other side approves the deal, both players get “signed” stamps and the deal takes effect.
executionOfObligations.tasks: As soon as both sides agree and form a long-term deal, it appears in the “my tasks” folder. Clicking the deal name expands detailed info. In this window we can track our deal duties, time limits, and pay/ship cats. Every action we need to take is highlighted as a new active task.
executionOfObligations.colors: Green numbers mean we are buying cats. Black numbers mean we are selling cats.
executionOfObligations.conditions: Clicking this button opens the long-term deal terms.

paymentSection.title: Payment
paymentSection.description: Payment is made manually via the expanded long-term deal info in the “my tasks” window.
paymentSection.success: After successful payment, a stamp appears next to the payment item. You can pay if you have enough funds.

workWithWarehouse.title: Warehouse work
workWithWarehouse.shipment: Shipping cats to the warehouse is done via the expanded long-term deal info in “my tasks.”
workWithWarehouse.restrictions: You can load only cats of the needed color to the warehouse; their quantity and health are at the sender’s discretion. You can’t load more cats than needed into the warehouse.
workWithWarehouse.inspection: Cat inspection and “before shipment” payment are done in “my tasks.” You can pay immediately to auto-confirm the warehouse, or before paying you can inspect the cats’ quality and quantity.
workWithWarehouse.verification: In the warehouse the number of cats is highlighted in several places, but to check health you need to inspect with the magnifier. If all cats are healthy and in the required quantity, you confirm them and pay “before shipment”.
workWithWarehouse.issues: But if you find a sick cat or the counterparty sent you an incomplete warehouse, you can confirm the warehouse or send a claim or fine. Don’t forget to check each sick cat.

claimsAndFines.title: Claims and fines
claimsAndFines.timer: If you were sent an incomplete batch of kittens or sick ones but the timer hasn’t expired, you can send only a claim or fully approve the deal.
claimsAndFines.fineOption: When the timer expires you can send a fine even if a claim has already been sent.
claimsAndFines.claim: A claim is an amicable settlement. This reminds the other side of its obligations.
claimsAndFines.fine: If a penalty is imposed, the other side must pay the fine agreed when concluding the long-term deal. The penalty also means the deal will be terminated and remaining obligations won’t be fulfilled.
claimsAndFines.receivedClaim: A claim was sent to you. You can complete the action to avoid a fine.
claimsAndFines.receivedFine: You were sent a fine; the deal is automatically terminated. You must pay it, or at the end of the season the fine amount will be deducted from your balance. If there aren’t enough funds, the bank guarantee will be triggered and you will be declared bankrupt.

terminationTransaction.title: Deal termination
terminationTransaction.unilateral: Unilateral termination without cause is paid with the pre-specified amount.
terminationTransaction.agreement: In termination by mutual agreement you specify the amount you will pay to terminate the deal, and send it for the counterparty’s approval.

seasonResults.title: Season results
seasonResults.description: Before each new season the player sees a modal with previous season results. It shows all money operations of the previous season.

gameResults.title: Game results
gameResults.description: At game end a modal window with results appears.
gameResults.contents: It contains the player list, placements, and how many coins each player had at game end.
gameResults.rating: The game ranking is based on players’ money at the end of the game. Kittens the cattery or pet shop didn’t sell are not counted.

business_plan_chapter1_welcome_title: welcome to Chapter 1 of Business Plan training
business_plan_chapter1_welcome_message: Let’s figure out why a business plan is needed—it helps build strategy, calculate all costs, forecast profit over the whole deal period, and present the project to stakeholders
business_plan_chapter1_business_plan_mes: To get a loan, the player must create a table with calculations for the seasons covered by the loan.
business_plan_chapter1_business_plan_fie: You see the chart fields—this is your future Business Plan, but it’s not filled yet
business_plan_chapter1_market_volume_mes: Knowing the estimated number of cats and their price, you can calculate the market “JUICY PART” all players will fight for
business_plan_chapter1_business_plan_eva: Before making the Business Plan, let’s evaluate the “SWEET SPOT”—our revenue from the deal
business_plan_chapter1_quantity_volume_t: QUANTITATIVE SIZE of the sweet spot
business_plan_chapter1_quantity_volume_m: Ginger cats are the most expensive, and we see demand for about 23 males and ~20 females
business_plan_chapter1_money_volume_titl: MONETARY SIZE OF THE SWEET SPOT
business_plan_chapter1_money_volume_mess: The shop is ready to buy 23 ginger males at 33 (that’s 759) and 20 ginger females at 36 (that’s 720). To find total market sweet spot, add boys and girls—gets 1479
business_plan_chapter1_market_volume_cal: 1479 - this is the very market sweet spot that players focusing on ginger kittens will fight for
business_plan_chapter1_our_volume_messag: We need to know what share of the market sweet spot is ours. We plan to place four ginger males and two ginger females in season five.
business_plan_chapter1_our_volume_calcul: We need to multiply the number of kittens we supply by their price. (4 ginger males * 33) + (2 ginger females * 36) = 132 + 72 = 204. 204 out of the 1479 sweet spot is our share of the market sweet spot, or our revenue, which is 14% of the total.
business_plan_chapter1_revenue_message: We need to fill the “revenue” field for season five; WE PLAN TO receive 204 from selling 6
business_plan_chapter1_planning_horizon_: we will take for the 5-season planning horizon—our full kitten-raising cycle
business_plan_chapter1_how_to_get_volume: How to claim the sweet spot?
To claim our sweet spot, we must calculate the expenses we’ll incur to reach it.
business_plan_chapter1_capex_message: The orange bar or “CAPEX” (capital expenditure) is capital investment in assets; in our case buying kittens and houses.
business_plan_chapter1_capex_calculation: We need to fill the “CAPEX” field in the first season, which includes the kittens and houses we’re buying. We’re buying one male costing 38, one female costing 42, and one house costing 3. Our total costs: 38 + 42 + 3 = 83
business_plan_chapter1_capex_real_life_m: Need to buy equipment: A new oven for baking bread is a capital expense since the oven is a long-term asset used for several years.
business_plan_chapter1_capex_real_life_2: investment in capital repair of premises: installing showcases, ventilation, hall decor—that is also CAPEX
business_plan_chapter1_opex_message: The next row is OPEX (operating expenditure)—operating costs for your activity; they show how much money you spend on cyclical operations; in our case utilities, feed, and treatment
business_plan_chapter1_opex_real_life_me: OPEX are operating expenses needed to keep the business running daily. For example, employee salaries: you pay bakers, cashiers, and cleaners—these are regular staff costs.
business_plan_chapter1_opex_real_life_2_: Buying raw materials: For baking bread and pies you monthly buy flour, sugar, butter, and other ingredients. Utilities: Electricity for ovens and water are necessary to run the business
business_plan_chapter1_opex_utilities_me: Each season from the first through the fifth you need to spend 3 on utilities. Enter 3 in the “OPEX - Utilities” fields in the required seasons
business_plan_chapter1_opex_utilities_ch: As soon as we filled the “OPEX - Utilities” field, we immediately see a maroon bar with horizontal red lines showing utility expenses.
business_plan_chapter1_opex_feed_message: Feed for 1 cat per season costs 1 starting from the next season after purchase. Don’t forget to feed cats on time or they will run away.
business_plan_chapter1_opex_feed_calcula: if a portion of feed costs 1, feed is needed in seasons 2,3,4 in amount 2 per season because we buy two cats.
business_plan_chapter1_opex_feed_input_m: Enter 2 in the “OPEX - Feed” fields in the required seasons.
business_plan_chapter1_opex_feed_chart_m: As soon as we filled the “OPEX - FEED” field, we immediately see a maroon row with vertical red lines showing feed expenses for kittens
business_plan_chapter1_opex_treatment_me: Once the kittens are born, we’ll need to treat them. Treatment includes either insuring the house for 3, or buying medicine for the kitten’s illnesses for 2 per sick kitten
business_plan_chapter1_opex_treatment_in: ...several kittens may get sick, so in the fourth season we will need to spend 3 on insuring the house with kittens. Enter 3 in “OPEX - TREATMENT”
business_plan_chapter1_opex_treatment_ch: As soon as we filled the “OPEX - TREATMENT” field, we immediately see on the chart a maroon row with red hatch lines showing treatment expenses for kitten offspring
business_plan_chapter1_expenses_message: Great, we set all costs for seasons 1–5; let’s calculate total expenses
business_plan_chapter1_shortage_funds_me: under “CAPEX” we bought cats - 80, and a house - 3. Total CAPEX 80 + 3 = 83. under “OPEX” we spent on utilities - 3 * 5 = 15 Feed - 2 * 3 = 6 Treatment - 3
business_plan_chapter1_shortage_funds_ca: As a result: CAPEX 83 + OPEX 24 = 107. WE need 107, but we don’t have that much money... part of this amount we can cover with “OWN FUNDS”
business_plan_chapter1_own_funds_message: The next field is “OWN FUNDS,” including use of our starting balance
business_plan_chapter1_own_funds_usage_m: BANKS LOVE it when a business invests its own funds in capital costs, so we will spend our entire starting balance in the first season to cover CAPEX costs
business_plan_chapter1_own_funds_input_m: fill the “OWN FUNDS” field in the first season to cover kitten purchases. starting balance is 40; enter this number
business_plan_chapter1_own_funds_chart_m: As soon as data is entered into the “Own funds” field, the chart immediately shows changes. In the first season a green row with purple outline appears—that’s the “Own funds”
business_plan_chapter1_own_funds_shortag: EVEN though we covered part of the costs with OWN FUNDS, we still lack coins, so we must take a loan for 107 - 40 = 67
business_plan_chapter1_investment_credit: “Investment loan” is taken for capital expenses needed to develop the company; in our case to buy kittens and a house for them. The “Investment loan” is the blue row with orange vertical lines.
We want to expand our bakery, buy equipment, but lack money, so we have one way—to the bank.

Such a loan is issued for specific business development purposes, assumes the borrower uses funds strictly as intended, and repayment is ensured by profit growth after implementing the investment project.
business_plan_chapter1_revolving_credit_: We want to expand our bakery, buy equipment, and took an investment loan for this, and need a revolving loan for operating expenses.
business_plan_chapter1_expenses_calculat: How to calculate how many of the missing 67 coins go to the investment loan and how many to the revolving? Subtract own funds from CAPEX to get coins for the investment loan 83 - 40 = 43. The remaining coins come from the revolving loan 67 - 43 = 24
business_plan_chapter1_revolving_credit_: To pay “opex feed/utilities/treatment” from seasons 2 to 5 inclusive we’ll need 24. Enter 24 in the “revolving loan” field in season 1. All this money will cover OPEX costs
business_plan_chapter1_credits_summary_m: As a result we arranged a loan totaling 67: of which 43 was an investment loan and 24 a revolving loan.
business_plan_chapter1_credit_body_remai: enter into the blue curve or “principal balance” the used credit line to be repaid under the loan terms
we will take two loans: Investment loan 43 and Revolving loan 24. 43 + 24 = 67 in the first season, and the credit line will not expand. fill the specified fields per calculation.
business_plan_chapter1_credit_body_payme: the red row or “loan principal payment” is the principal payment amount without interest.
Since revenue is only in the fifth season, fill the “loan principal payment” field in season 5, enter 67
business_plan_chapter1_credit_percentage: The maroon row with a red outline or “Loan interest payment” is interest payment. When planning a loan, we can choose any rate and agree it with the bank.
business_plan_chapter1_conditions_modal_: As part of the training, the “Terms” window shows the credit terms from the bot-bank. The bot can give a loan at 15%, which suits us. Click the “Exit” button
business_plan_chapter1_credit_percentage: In total we plan to take a loan of 67 at 15% interest. Interest is calculated by: (67 * 15%) * 4 seasons = 40.20. Since the interest number isn’t whole, round up the total interest for the seasons and get 41
total overpayment interest will be 41. That suits us since we’ll earn more coins and can close the loan easily. Remember in the real game you negotiate the loan rate with the bank.
fill the “% on the loan” field in season 5 and enter 41
business_plan_chapter1_profit_calculatio: LET’S CALCULATE OUR FINAL PROFIT IT IS CALCULATED BY THE FORMULA (INCOME - EXPENSE = PROFIT) OUR INCOME IS 204 (revenue) EXPENSE IS capex + opex + loan % 83 + 24 +41 = 148. 204 - 148 = 56. 56 is our final profit
business_plan_chapter1_profit_input_mess: Profit is positive even with interest payments, so it makes sense to take a loan for this project. Enter 56 in the “PROFIT” field in the “TOTAL” column
business_plan_chapter1_final_straight_me: Now we’ll reveal the secret; ready?
business_plan_chapter1_final_straight_2_: The world isn’t perfect; something will go wrong, for example kitten prices may suddenly drop.
business_plan_chapter1_stress_scenario_m: Usually banks don’t accept a business plan without a stress scenario reducing total revenue by 25%, so: Price of males 33 * 75% = 24. price of females 36 * 75% = 27. 24 * 4 + 27 * 2 = 150
business_plan_chapter1_deal_submission_m: 150 - 148 = 2. Even under the stress scenario we’ll have a small profit. The business plan in the optimistic and base scenario is ready; you can send the deal to the bank.
business_plan_chapter1_congratulations_m: To reach the next level, complete the practical task.
business_plan_chapter1_task_message: Now you need to independently create a business plan and send it to the bank for loan approval. Goal: correctly account for all expenses and get positive profit by season 5, buy kittens in season 1 and sell all offspring. Use a loan in season 1 covering CAPEX and OPEX.

business_plan_chapter2_welcome_title: welcome to the chapter “Long-term deals in the business plan”
business_plan_chapter2_welcome_message: In the previous chapter we studied key aspects of creating a business plan, but didn’t cover how to adjust it when focusing on a long-term deal
business_plan_chapter2_intro_title: Long-term deals in the business plan
business_plan_chapter2_intro_message: Long-term deals let you receive part of the revenue in advance to cover capital or operating costs, and together with investment and revolving loans achieve impressive profit
business_plan_chapter2_task_message_line: Your task is to independently develop a business plan considering payment periods and bank guarantee.
Goal: correctly account for all expenses and payment timing, achieve positive profit by season 5, buy kittens in season 1 and sell all offspring. Use a loan in season 1 covering CAPEX and OPEX.
